title: Stylistic Alternates
content:
After following the Cyrillic Small Caps thread below, I got   
to wondering about OT support between applications.   
For instance, Illustrator CS supports Stylistic Alternates   
while InDesign CS doesn't. (they can be manually added   
via the glyph pallete but it tends to be clunky compared   
to the ease with which Illustrator CS can do it)   
   
Any thoughts?

 [‹ FontLab's Bitfonter for pixelfonts designers..?](http://web.archive.org/web/20080113203051/http:/www.typophile.com/node/1098 "Go to previous forum topic") [Cyrillic/Russian Small Caps in InDesign ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080113203051/http:/www.typophile.com/node/2826 "Go to next forum topic")
author: eolson

comments.content: Since when does ID CS not support stylistic alternatives?
Hmm, I guess it doesn't. Unless I'm missing something. I thought it did.

Different groups with Adobe are responsible for defining the feature set of their apps. The \<salt\> feature is something of a peculiarity as it may be implemented with GSUB type 1 lookups (one-to-one) or type 3 lookups (one-to-one-of-many). Apparently the InDesign team decided not to support the feature at all until they are able to support the type 3 lookup, while the Illustrator team decided to provide support by treating the first enumerated glyph of a type 3 lookup as if it were a type 1 lookup. So Illustrator provides partial support for the \<salt\> feature (so, by the way, does InDesign Middle East).

After buying the new CS package I have to say I was   
a little surprised by the way each program supports OT.   
   
From a type designers standpoint the \<salt\> feature is   
very helpful. Alternate letters are actually not that   
uncommon so why not put them all into in a single file?   
Old news of course, but what is the best way to do it   
without leaving InDesign users out of the picture?
